channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘The Autobots’ Hits Theaters, and Many Chinese Say They’ve Seen It Before
item.description: One of the country’s newest movies has drawn criticism for bearing a more-than-uncanny resemblance to Disney-Pixar’s hit franchise “Cars.”
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Replicas of two characters from the Disney film "Cars" at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: A Sliver of Opportunity Emerges in the Gaza Strip
item.description: Robert Turner, who is leaving his post as the Gaza director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, said that there are some positive signs amid the poverty and hopelessness there.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Stock Sell-Off Is Unabated in China
item.description: Despite further steps by Beijing to calm trading, shares plunged, extending a rout that began last month.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A board displaying stock prices at a brokerage house in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Greece Submits New Loan Request, as Tsipras Takes Defiant Stance
item.description: Under a tight deadline from European leaders, Greece applied for a three-year bailout loan, and the prime minister took his case to the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Election Seen as Crucial Step for Myanmar Set for Nov. 8
item.description: A general election seen as a crucial next step for Myanmar's transition to democracy has been scheduled for Nov. 8.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Plunge in Chinese Stocks Leads to Bull Market for Gallows Humor
item.description: On social media the market routs and fumbling government efforts to stop them have triggered an explosion of jokes, as Chinese investors try to find ways to ease the pain.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Investors discussing stock prices at a trading firm in Hangzhou on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Finds Another Real-Life Spinoff of ‘Breaking Bad’
item.description: Officials have arrested a chemistry professor suspected of producing and selling a psychoactive drug, and the state news agency is calling him “China’s real-life Walter White.”
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Bryan Cranston as Walter White in the series "Breaking Bad."

item.title: Srebrenica Massacre, After 20 Years, Still Casts a Long Shadow in Bosnia
item.description: Remains are still being unearthed from the killing of about 8,000 men and boys in 1995 in the worst atrocity committed in Europe since World War II.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A worker digging a grave at the Srebrenica-Potocari Memorial in Bosnia ahead of Saturday's ceremony for the 20th anniversary of the massacre.

item.title: Moscow Journal: Russian Belts Tighten, Affecting Tastes for the Finer Things
item.description: In Russia, endurance of financial pain is a point of national pride. But as some make do, others forgo villas and other luxuries or invest elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house for sale in Rublovka, a patchwork of gated communities combining vast wealth with often dubious taste. Though just a short drive from Moscow, the elaborate home has yet to sell.

item.title: Ron Pollard, a Pioneer in Britain’s Betting Industry, Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Pollard was widely credited with introducing betting on British politics, extending the bookmaking business beyond horse and dog racing to politics, beauty contests, sports and Elvis sightings.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Ron Pollard in 1978 at Hickstead in West Sussex, England.

item.title: 3 Saudi Brothers Held in Kuwait Mosque Attack
item.description: The suicide attack on June 26 killed 26 people, plus the bomber, and was Kuwait’s deadliest militant attack.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Open Source: Tourists on Greek Island Join Local Volunteers to Aid Refugees
item.description: On the island of Lesbos, some tourists have taken time away from the beach to help refugees fleeing Syria.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: Guatemala: Ex-Dictator Is Found Unfit
item.description: Prosecutors say José Efraín Rios Montt is responsible for the deaths of 1,771 Mayan Indians killed by the army.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Burundi: Victory for Governing Party
item.description: Burundi has been rocked by protests because of President Pierre Nkurunziza’s push for a third term in office in elections set for next Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Market’s Dive Could Delay Economic Reforms in China
item.description: China has been introducing changes in its banking sector and at state-owned companies, but the pace of reforms could slow if the market slump persists.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The opening ceremony in November of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect program. Plans for a similar link with Shenzen could be postponed.

item.title: World Briefing: Liberia: Dog Suspected in New Ebola Case Tests Negative for the Virus
item.description: Liberia’s first victim of the virus since the country was declared Ebola-free in early May had eaten dog meat shortly before he died on June 28.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Top Court Rules for Family of Patient in a Right-to-Die Case
item.description: Argentina’s Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Marcelo Diez, who has required life support for two decades, can be allowed to die.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Juli Soler, the El Bulli Restaurateur Who Changed Dining, Dies at 66
item.description: Mr. Soler and Ferran Adrià turned El Bulli in Spain into the most daring and influential restaurant of its time.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Juli Soler, right, the co-owner of El Bulli, with Ferran Adrià, the chef and co-owner, announcing the closing of their restaurant in Spain in 2011.

item.title: Pope Francis, in Ecuador, Calls for More Protection of Rain Forest and Its People
item.description: Francis declared that the country must resist exploiting natural riches for “short-term benefits,” an implicit rebuke of President Rafael Correa’s policies.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis, center, arrived Tuesday to celebrate Mass at Bicentenario Park in Quito, Ecuador.

item.title: Obama Hosts a Top Official From Vietnam at Oval Office
item.description: President Obama’s meeting with the Communist official, Nguyen Phu Trong, was timed to mark the 20th anniversary of normalized relations between the onetime war enemies.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
